keyTakeAways: A runner from Auckland, New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the woods near Myoko, Japan, during a routine run.
The bear attack resulted in a broken arm and leg injuries, requiring three surgeries including a hip graft and metal plates in the arm.
Bear attacks in Japan have increased dramatically, with over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported this year — the highest since 2006.
Experts attribute the rise in bear encounters to climate change disrupting traditional food sources, forcing bears into urban and suburban areas.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the surge in attacks.
Local residents use methods like carrying bells or blasting music to deter bears, and Halloran now plans to carry bear spray.
Halloran, despite trauma and ongoing recovery, remains committed to returning to running and nature, emphasizing community support and personal resilience.
The incident highlights a growing global issue: climate change-driven animal behavior shifts threatening human safety in previously safe environments.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while running in the woods near Myoko, Japan. The attack caused severe injuries, including a broken arm and leg, requiring multiple surgeries and long-term rehabilitation. This incident occurs amid a significant rise in bear attacks in Japan — over 100 injuries and seven deaths this year — attributed to climate change disrupting traditional bear food sources and forcing them into human areas. The Japanese government has responded by announcing stricter measures to control bear populations. Halloran, though traumatized, remains determined to return to running and nature, underscoring both the personal and societal implications of this growing environmental and public safety crisis.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
